ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] fact check
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Insofar as SOAP is often contrasted with HTTP/XML , perhaps.  But I m just generally uncomfortable with the association of REST and XML. YMMV, of course.

On Sun, Oct 24, 2004 at 08:15:39PM -0500, R. Mark Volkmann wrote:
> >On Sun, Oct 24, 2004 at 03:30:44PM -0500, R. Mark Volkmann wrote:
> >
> >>REST doesn't mandate the use of XML for the content of request and 
> >>response
> >>messages, but XML is the most common data representation used in 
> >>messages.
> >
> >Not by a long shot.  I'd expect that HTML is far and away the most
> >popular format.  RSS is probably the most popular XML based format,
> >but way behind HTML.
> 
> Maybe I should clarify that I'm looking at REST from the standpoint of 
> being an alternative to SOAP, not as a way of constructing a web app. In 
> that setting it seems much more desirable for a REST service to return XML 
> than HTML, correct?

Insofar as SOAP is often contrasted with "HTTP/XML", perhaps.  But I'm
just generally uncomfortable with the association of REST and XML.
YMMV, of course.

Perhaps it would be best to say something to the effect that REST
doesn't prescribe any particular data format, but since XML is all
the rage, using XML in the context of a RESTful app is what a lot of
people are doing.

> I assumed that using REST as an alternative to SOAP was the most common use 
> of REST. Is that wrong? 

*shrug* I would hope REST is used to help people build better apps for
the Web, but I don't know.

Mark.
--
